description: From Middle English placebo, from Latin placēbō (“I will please”), the first-person singular future active indicative of placeō (“I please”).

entries.meaning: (medicine) A dummy medicine containing no active ingredients; an inert treatment. [from 18th c.]
examples: The acid test, I thought, was whether homeopathic remedies behave differently from placebos when submitted to clinical trials.

entries.meaning: (Roman Catholicism) The vespers sung in the office for the dead. [from 13th c.]
examples: There the placebo, the office for the dead, was sung, and a vigil kept throughout the night.
